text: Joe sits in a middle row, doodling. The science teacher, FERRARA (40s) fires questions at the class.
In any ecosystem we have indigenous flora and...? Robert?
Shale?

No, not shale...I like where you’re head’s at though... Ferrara hears Joe doodling in the otherwise silent class. Joe doesn’t notice Ferrara approaching. We see the drawin Joe, on horseback, riding into the FOREST. A girl rides w him, clutching him around the waist. He colors her dress with a YELLOW HIGHLIGHTER. Ferrara STOMPS HIS FOOT once loudly next to Joe, snapping out of his artistic trance.
Joe Toy. Flora and?
(turning page) Fauna.
Very good. An allamanda cathartica would be an example of which? (off Joe’s silence) And an allamanda cathartica would be an example of which?
I’ve never heard those words before in my life.
That was my hope. No drawing in class, please. Allamanda cathartica. Allamanda cathartica. (noticing a raised hand) Kelly. We land on KELLY (15), a pretty girl...in a YELLOW DRESS.

Flora. When Ferrara turns his back, Joe and Kelly make eye conta Joe rolls his eyes at her ass-kissing. She sticks her ton out. They’re clearly buddies. EXT. TOTTENVILLE HIGH SCHOOL - 2 P.M. School’s out. Students crowd the sidewalk. Joe walks his bicycle alongside him, keeping pace with Kelly.
What were you drawing in there? It was obviously top secret.
Oh. Just some...blueprints. Patrick and me are working on this bike ramp thing.
Blueprints? Huh. That’s funny.
Funny?
You just don’t strike me as like a “man’s man,” y'know? Construction and all. That’s not an insult. Beat on Joe. Smiling, but insulted.
How's Patrick doing, by the way?
He's fine. I think he’s supposed to come back next week.
I was gonna say, if you guys want, you should come to Thirsty Thursdays tomorrow night.
“Thirsty Thursdays.” I have no idea what that is.

It’s a keg. At Wolf’s Pond. Paul’s friends throw it every week once it starts getting warm out and ohmygod-- The boyfriend approaches, PAUL: 17, could be 36. Goatee, earring. He’s bleeding noticeably from the shoulder.
What happened??
Hm? Some dog bit me. I’m fine. He kisses her ‘hello’ on the mouth.
What? For no reason??
Well I was hitting him and shit. (to Joe) What’s up man.
Oh -- Paul, you know Joe. We have Bio together.
(handshake) Yow.
(inspecting the wound) Should we go to the hospital?
No. You want a bagel? C’mon. I want an egg bagel.
Ugh! (to Joe) He always gets hurt, and he never goes to the doctor. Joe raises his eyebrows in false fascination.
Starving, babe.
Okay, okay. See you tomorrow, Joe! Joe waves, watching as Paul leads her away, shoving his h into Kelly's back pocket as they walk. Off his misery:
Joe rides his bike home from school. We get an impression the town: a bank, a church, a barbershop. Quaint.

Joe steers through a narrow “trail” in the woods. It’s de with trees and brush. Craning up above the trees, we see that the woods are bordered on all sides by tracts of suburban houses. In th deep distance, factory pipes. Off the sound of a DOORBELL:  EXT. PATRICK’S HOUSE - DAY Joe waits on the stoop. The door opens to reveal MRS. MCGUIRE, 42. Patrick’s mom.
Patrick home?
Come in, Joseph.
A modest country-theme home. Thomas Kinkade and Precious Moments abound.
(calling upstairs) Patrick! Joseph's here.
I’m coming down.
Stay where you are! He will come to you!

I’m fine, ma! At the top of the stairs, PATRICK MCGUIRE comes into view Though also 14, he’s a brick shithouse, a man by any phys standard. There’s an AIR CAST on his left foot. He hops down one step at a time.
Mother Cabrini, protect my son.
Stop praying, ma. Another few steps. Painstaking.
Look at you! You're sweating. You’re sweating from the pain!
I‘m sweating from you, ma. Two more stairs. He’s winded now.
I’m getting you a cold washcloth.
I don’t want one.
Well it’s happening. How about you, Joseph? Would you like a cold washcloth?
I would take one, yeah.
No one is getting a cold washcloth.
On TV: “STREET FIGHTER 2” for Super Nintendo. The boys si in spitting distance of the screen, concentrating.
My mom reminds me of Blanka.
Because she wears cutoff jeans?
No, because everything she says, in my head, sounds like Blanka’s crazy victory roar. Listen. On TV: After a knockout, BLANKA stands on his hind legs a roars three times.
That’s the sound I hear whenever she speaks. Just the jibberish of an undisciplined animal.
You hear that all day?
All day. He pauses the game.
I have to get out of this house, man.
What do you mean?
I mean I can’t stand another minute of it. Of them. They’re down my throat all day. They don’t stop.
Well, you'll be back at school Monday, right? You can tough it out.
No, you don’t get it. They’re killing me. Like, I’m getting hives.
No you’re not. Patrick lifts his shirt: a few small hives are scattered his torso.
shit.
Yeah, shit is right.
Family dinner. Joe sits with his father, FRANK (51), and sister LISA (19), who wears a college-team hoodie.
Daddy, can Colin come tomorrow? He really wants to meet you guys.
Can I get some sweet potato casserole? (then) Who's Colin?
He's my boyfriend of seven months.
Hm. What are his prospects? How does he plan to support you?
He’s Sri Lankan.
Right, right. Aren’t we all. (passing food) Put that back over by you. Move the water.
Speaking of tomorrow -- can you drive me to Wolf’s Pond at like 8? Joe notices Frank staring at him in mild shock.
What?
Tomorrow. Thursday night, Joe. What do you think we’re sitting here talking about?
What are we talking about?
Is this a joke? Carol is coming over Thursday. We’re having Game Night. I told you about this weeks ago.
You never told me about that!
That's horseshit, Joe. I told you at least twice, and I watched you write it on your forearm in permanent marker. Joe glances at his forearm. There is some faded text.
Well what if I don’t want to meet “Carol”? I don’t make you meet all the girls I bang out. Lisa snickers.
This is not a debate, Joe! The plans are made. (MORE )
Just be there, and be pleasant. She’s making lamb stew for us. She’s going out of her way.
Lamb stew? What is this, Beowulf? I’m not touching it.
Believe me, you’re touching it.
It'll be fun, Joe. You'll get to meet Colin.
(to Lisa) I think I’m done hearing that name tonight, okay? Joe simmers at Frank, livid.
What, Joe. Joe rises silently and moves to the wall phone.
What are you doing? Joe picks up the receiver and shoots Frank a threatening look.

We’re supposed to be past this, Joseph! For Christ’s sake! Remember what we talked about. Think of people who really need to call 911! A moment of tension. Then, Joe opens the dishwasher, shov the phone in, and leaves.
(after him) I don’t know who that’s supposed to be hurting!
Joe watches as his friend ANGELO, 14, sticks a large FIRECRACKER into a mailbox. Angelo turns to flee.  10.
Come on come on come on! They run across the street and hide behind some shrubs. A nebbishy kid, AARON (also 14), waits for them there. They stare at the mailbox. Nothing happens.
Did it light? The mailbox EXPLODES.
Ha! Got you. / Remarkable. An INDIAN GUY, 30s, comes out and immediately spots the b
We tired of this game yet?
Not till you learn English, dot- head!
Huh?? I have a double masters from Georgetown. Your father cleans pools.
Go home! In the background, a storm door opens on one of the house A little old Italian lady pokes her head out. Angelo’S MO ANGELO’S MOM Angelo! Venire all'interno e spostare vestiti!
Essere di destra 1a! She retreats inside.
Shit. I gotta go shift the wash. (to Indian guy) Fuck you, Mola Ram!!
What?!  11.
I’m out too. Thirsty Thursdays.
Oh God. You’re going to that?
Of course. Everyone’s going.
Not me. My goddam shit-eating father won’t let me. (then) And Kelly invited me too.
So what, Kelly invited you. She's got a boyfriend. Who’s twice your size.
Right. The cave troll. What’s his name again? Ju’tuun?
Paul. I can’t believe that guy is seventeen years old. He looks like he works for Con Ed.
Yeah. (frustrated) Shit.

Well no big deal, man. There will be other...best times of your life. INT. JOE’S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Game night. Lisa, Frank and Joe sit around a monopoly boa joined by COLIN, 19, bookish; and CAROL, 40, far too good this situation. Joe sits slumped, miserable.
Carol, the lamb was delicious. Very tender. It felt like I was chewing avocado meat.  12.
Thanks Colin. I boil it first.
I thought you might have. I didn’t want to presume.
Colin, no one knows what you're talking about. Carol ROLLS. Marvin Gardens.
Meh. Pass.
Passing on Marvin Gardens? Ballsy.
Well look at this. I’m broke.

You pissed it all away on purples. (going through her cards) What the hell is this, Virginia? If you’re gonna rely on colors, go red, orange, yellow. Strong colors. They attract the eye. People want to land there. They will themselves to.
Royal blue. Also a fierce color.
Colin, again, we’re unclear as to what you’re saying. Joe sits up.
Don’t listen to this clown. His whole game is railroads. He’s got blinders on to the world.
Who’s “he”? I’m right here.
Blinders.  13.
People need transportation, Joe. They need to get from A to B. Joe points his hands out from his temples: Blinders. He does.
Just roll, Frank.
Lisa, do you remember when you bought B&O and wouldn’t trade him, and he quit?
I didn't “quit.” I just wasn’t having fun anymore. Why would I play if I’m not having fun? What’s the point of a game? People play games to heighten life, to forget themselves.
That's beautiful.
Shut the fuck up, Colin.
(laughing) Is that true, Frank? You actually quit Monopoly? How old are you? Frank tenses up, uncomfortable.
Oh yeah, he always quits. He once quit because Lisa hit free parking six times.

Any sane person would have walked away from that game. Something wasn’t right and you goddam know it. Carol laughs, and Joe joins her. Frank shoots Joe a look. Joe shoots one back, relishing the moment of comeuppance. Frank moves his gamepiece.  14.
I will absolutely buy that... (counting out money) Hello Colin.
Hello.
Do you want to be my friend?
Very badly, sir. Joe watches this exchange, not trusting it.
Okay then. Right now -- Tennessee and St. James. I'’11 give you Park Place and Indiana.
Whoa whoa whoa whoa--
Let the men talk, Joseph. On Joe: fuming.
Yes. Clearly, yes I would do that.
Frank, that makes no sense. He’ll kill us all.
There will be collateral damage, yes. But war is hell. Joe looks at the board -- he sees what’s happening. His piece is in jail. Frank’s building on orange. It’s a setu
(to himself) He’s pricing me out...
What’s that?
(big smile) Your roll, Joey Joe-Joe.  15.
This is bullshit, Dad! You're pricing me out of the goddam game!
(eyeing board) Oh man...he is.
Oh come on Frank. He’s your son.
You can’t do that Dad! It’s collusion.

I can do whatever I want, Joe. My house, my rules. Frank lights a cigar and leans back. A suburban Bugsy. He smiles at Joe, rubbing it in. Joe’s lip quivers, but he tries not to break, tries not to give Frank the satisfact
Let’s just have a fun game. No?

Hey, I’m not the one who started telling fun little, funny little stories. He’s just mad because he doesn’t want to be here, so he’s being a shit. (then) Roll the die, Joe. Let’s see what happens. If you need a loan, maybe we can work something out at a fair interest rate. A tense, miserable beat of silence. Then Joe rises, heads for the kitchen.
That was a cruel thing to do, Frank.
Is he quitting? INT. JOE’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Joe, red-faced, picks up the wall phone. INSERT - A switchboard operator picks up.  16.
911, what is your emergency? BACK IN JOE’S HOUSE: Frank knows what’s happening.
Ah shit -- he’s doing it! Frank darts at Joe, but Joe runs into the bathroom and lo the door. INT. JOE’S BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Joe sits on the toilet, covering his ear.
(into phone) I want to report a theft...yes +..up to one thousand dollars in cash and assets...
Hang it up Joe!
(into phone) 28 Rye Avenue. No, he’s actually in the house right now... Loud BANGING as Frank attempts to break the door down. Jo moves toward the corner of the room.

(into phone) His name is Frank Toy, brown hair...height unknown...He’s obsessed with railroads... The door SPLINTERS. INT. JOE’S ROOM - NIGHT Through Joe’s window, we see Frank talking to two police officers. He holds the Monopoly board and makes desperate animated gestures. The officers nod. Move back to reveal Joe, watching, holding a flashlight. room is dark.  17. He shines the flashlight in short spurts out the window. dot-dot, dash-dash-dash, dot-dot-dot... After a few beats, we hear THUMPING from outside. Feet climbing stairs. Frank opens the door.

Stop signaling. Joe shines the flashlight beam into Franks’s eyes. Frank squints and shuts the door. Joe lies on the bed, miserable. He spins something around between his thumb and forefinger. Flashlight on: a small green MONOPOLY HOUSE. He looks at it, then past it, and freezes...something caught his eye. The wall across from him: Though we notice an “Excalibur” poster and other assorted nerd items, Joe’s focus is on t huge SHADOW being cast by the monopoly house. Joe regards this “house” shape... Then shines the flashlight across the room, illuminating TOOLBOX sitting atop his dresser. Beat on Joe, thinking...
Patrick enters on his boot, carrying a team duffel bag. T teacher conducts the class to recite the words on the boa
Recepcidn detrds, Patrick! They applaud. Patrick smiles through the awkwardness.
Patrick recites translations, sitting by the window.
éQué color es perros?

(with the class) Algunos perros son marrén, algunos perros son negro, algunos --  18. The sound of KNOCKING breaks his concentration -- Joe's outside, at the window. Behind him, a scrawny, olive-skin kid sits on a bicycle: BIAGGIO, 14, quiet but dedicated. Joe makes a “come here” motion. Patrick turns his palms upward in a gesture of powerlessness.
(mouthing the words) Come outside for a second. A stern Patrick points to his desk, then points to the fr of the classroom.
(mouthing) Come on. One second. Patrick writes something on loose leaf and presses it aga the window. It says “I am in school right now”
Joe and Biaggio sit on the window ledge. Patrick sees fro the corner of his eye, then shakes his head. Joe takes a sandwich out of his bag, prepared to wait it out.
Patrick, éCémo viejo es tu perro?

(caught off guard) Um, no tengo un perro, profesor. TEACHER’S VOICE Who are those boys outside? Does anyone know those boys? Are they your friends, Dudley? A black kid behind Patrick picks his head up.
Patrick’s been talking to them for five minutes, man! Why do I get blamed? TEACHER’S VOICE Because of what you are!  19.
Patrick walks across the street with Joe.
Don’t do that shit anymore. You're gonna get me in trouble.
I would get detention, not you. You did nothing wrong. A car full of students drives by. A kid hanging out the window hollers “McGuire!” Patrick absently waves.
How do you never get caught? What about the truant officer?
Yeah, the truant officer. He’s fucking 19. I'11 shit in his mouth. Cutaway to a baby faced Cop-in-a-Box idling on the curb.
(hopping on his bike) Get on.
Biaggio hacks through brush with a MACHETE. Joe and Patri walk the dirt path behind him.
Come on man. I can’t walk all day like this.
We’re almost there. Fifty more yards, about.
Almost where? What’s happening right now??  20.
The come to a large, treeless area. No civilization in sight. Joe walks to the epicenter, the about-faces and stretched his arms, like “welcome.”
Do you want your room facing sunrise, or the sunset?
What are you talking about?
Our new house. No, “home.” We’re building a home on this very spot.
What, like a tree-house?
No, like a living-house -- I’m moving out. And I want you to come with me. Biaggio thrusts a shovel toward Patrick.
Who is this kid? (to Biaggio) Who the fuck are you?
It's Biaggio.
Biaggio? What are you, an exchange student?
He’s been in our class since the 4th grade. (beat) We’ll get to him later man - are you in? Patrick rubs his eyes. Joe isn’t kidding.
You're serious about this.  21.

Of course I’m serious. Look, you can’t live with your parents, I certainly can’t live with Shit-Ass Frank any more. If we do this we can make our own rules, make our own choices! Live and die by our wits, like men! What do we need? A few 2x10s and a foundation?
It’s not that simple, Joe.
It is, man. With my mind, and your hands, we can pull this off. We’re preternaturally skilled craftsmen.
Joe, we almost built a ramp, and I got a 92 in Shop. That doesn’t mean we can build a house!
Come on man. Break ground with me. You’re my best friend. Biaggio looks at Joe, crestfallen.
(to Biaggio) Don’t take that to heart Biaggio. Who knows what the future holds. (to Patrick) Well? Patrick takes a deep breath.
Look, I won’t tell anyone what you're doing, I promise. But this is insane. You know that, right? Joe's last resort:
It’s this or the hives, man. Silence.
I’1l see you later.  22. Patrick boots off into the forest.
Patrick jams him palm into a Heinz bottle, drizzling ketc on a burger. Mom and Dad sit on either side.
I got the chop chuck from DeMonte’s instead of King Kullen. So the hamburgers might taste a little different. But they might taste the same. It’s fun to try new things, though.
(to Patrick) What did Coach Locke say when he saw you?
Nothing. He just said he was glad to have me back.
I saw your sub play last Thursday. “Moscato,” they called him.
Yes. That’s his last name.
I didn’t like him. He had a weak chin. (looking at Patrick’s plate) You do that often? You eat the hamburger, then the fries? You don’t mix it up?
I don’t know. Sometimes.
Patrick, have you heard about this Die Hard movie? Die Hard 5? It’s set in outer space.
Huh?  23.
Mmm...It’s not a Die Hard movie. I think it’s called Festival something.
Yes, that’s the one -- Festival. Bruce Die Hard is in it, though. Are you gonna go see Festival with your friends?
“Festival.”
Are you talking about “The Fifth Element”??
Right! The Elements. It looks very impressive. Tell us how it is.
Did I say I was seeing it? I have no interest in it.
Yes, it's with Bruce Element, and the other one, who’s the bad guy? He’s been in a lot, he's very good. “Samuel Clemens.”
His name is not Samuel Clemens.
Well the actor, not the character.
(rubs his eyes) I know what you mean. Samuel Clemens is Mark Twain's pen name. The actor is Gary Oldman.
Mm...no, that doesn't sound right.
Well maybe you guys should go see it! Treat yourselves. Get out of the house for a night.  24.
Maybe we will.
(re: Patrick's food) The flavors compliment each other, if you wanted to do some of one, then some of the other.
(agitated) I know, Dad.
Your Aunt Janette is coming Friday afternoon, Patrick. I told her you'll be around. I’m going to put some cashews out.
I don’t have to call her ‘aunt’ anymore, right? I’m fourteen. She’s of no blood relation. You went to camp with her.
She loves you like an aunt, she showers you with gifts.
She loves you, Patrick.
She gets me weird things that I don’t want. She got me a wood- burning kit.
I know she did. And now it just sits there. Too much goes to waste in this world. Patrick just shakes his head. He bites into his burger. M McGuire can’t stop staring at Patrick’s plate.
Is that a usual thing for you, though? (to wife) He eats all of one food, and then moves onto all of another food.  25.
So what?!
Come on. That’s how the blind eat. We didn’t raise you to do that. To be blind.
(losing it) But how does it affect you?? Why comment on it?? Out of nowhere, Mom starts WHISTLING.
Can you whistle? Can you whistle, Patrick? I have to breath in to do it.

No no no. You’re supposed to breath out. Let the diaphragm support it. They both whistle out of key with one another. Patrick lo some color in his face and starts breathing erratically. INT. JOE'S BEDROOM/PATRICK’S BEDROOM - NIGHT The phone RINGS. Joe answers right away.
Hello? Cut to Patrick’s (intercut between rooms as needed). He’s standing in front of a full length mirror, covered in HIV
I’m in.
What? Huh?
I’m in, I said. The house. I'11 do it.
(grinning) Fuckin...yes! Awesome man...okay, we break ground tomorrow at 5AM. Good shit!  26.
How about eleven?
Eleven’s fine. INT. KELLY’S ROOM - THE NEXT MORNING Kelly sits on her bed listening to a CD. A KNOCK on her door, then a Mom-type opens it. KELLY’S MOM Kel -- Vicki's coming up.
Okay. The best friend, VICKI (15) enters. Dark hair, dark soul.
You’re not gonna believe this. She hands Kelly a magazine.
‘Architectural Digest.’ So?
Turn to page 23. Kelly turns. We see a feature on JOE, standing before his pristine new House in the Woods.
Oh my God! Joe Toy??
He built that house with his bare hands.
Wait -- he built this??
Well, Patrick and Biaggio helped with parts and labor, but the whole thing was Joe’s baby. God, a guy who can work with his hands... that’s the ultimate.  27.
(reading) It’s got a game room... and a botanical garden...and a lazy river!
Ugh. He must be rich.
Rich, or just brilliant. And crafty as hell. Tight on Kelly, lost in the article.
I can’t believe a man like this has been under my nose for a whole year. We hear more KNOCKING. It seems to come from far away...
INT. JOE’S SHOWER - REAL LIFE, 10AM The knocking snaps Joe out of his DAYDREAM. He’s showerin His hair is sculpted into a shampoo mohawk.

Joe! You’ve been in there for fifty-five minutes! INT. JOE’S HOUSE, UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER Frank waits outside the door, messy and unshaven. The wat turns off. He knocks again. INT. JOE’S BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Joe brushes his teeth. He shoots a contemptuous glance at the door.
Let’s go. I have a tee time.
Frank knocks again.  28.
You have to talk to me eventually, Joe. Silence. After a beat, Joe runs out, naked and still soak His hands are cupped over his genitals.
(averting his eyes) Jesus. As Joe scampers into his room:

You’ve gotta bring underwear in with you, Joe! You're 14 years old! It’s not cute anymore! EXT. JOE’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Bird's eye of Joe bursting out of his side gate on his bi We move up and over the rooftops, heading past subdivisio strip malls, until the woods appear in the distance. We m in until treetops fill the frame. We linger on the dense green tableau. It could be anywhere in the world.
Patrick, Joe and Biaggio stand in a large rectangular hol the earth, DIGGING. Judging by the stains and general demeanor, the fun part is over. We hear grunts, wheezing.
(to Biaggio) Did you talk to your father about concrete?
He says it’s impossible, and he says if I ask again he’s going to throw my binder in the garbage.
(stops shoveling) Well shit man, where does that leave us?
Relax, we’ll think of a substitute. We could use sod, we could use clay, we--  29.
This isn’t the fucking French Open, Joe! We need a concrete foundation. That’s like rule one.
We could use dirt. Pack it hard.
You want to fill this hole with dirt? Biaggio shrugs. Patrick throws his shovel and climbs out the hole.
Where are you going? Relax man! This is a flawed process.
(climbing) No shit. Call me when you have some idea what’s going on.
C'mon, keep your eye on the prize here! We need you, Tum Tum!
And we're not using nicknames from “Three Ninjas,” either. Patrick is gone. Biaggio starts after him, but Joe stops him.
Let him go, Colt.
Joe walks in, utterly filthy. The door chimes. Guy behind the counter:
Not cool, guys. I just had the floors buffed yesterday. By the refrigerators, Patrick, also very filthy, browses drinks. Joe approaches.
How can I make you happy here?  30.
(hands Joe a Snapple) First, you’re gonna buy me a Guava Mania. Second, I want you to make a fucking plan! Read a book!
Hey man, I never said it would be easy, I just said it would be worth it. Good things come to those who wait. Friends are the best therapy.
I’ve been to your house, asshole! Those are your refrigerator magnets. Patrick moves up an aisle. Joe follows.
Fine. I'11 do some research, okay? We both will. Patrick hands Joe a box of frozen waffles.

These are coming too. (back on subject) I’ve done the research, Joe! Did you know that pine cones are a legitimate source of fiber? That the red baneberry is edible, but the white one is deadly? That skunk spray can blind you? No, you didn’t.

(sigh) Yes, fine, you know things. But no one learns as much from books as they do from actual real life, okay? You can bring a fucking meat thermometer and your Cub Scout manual if you want, but at some point we’re gonna have to dick up and trust our instincts.. ATTENDANT’S VOICE Yo! Out of the store! Not gonna say it again!
(ignoring attendant) Joe, all I'm saying is, let’s do this right. (MORE )
I’m not in the mood for another Joe Toy disaster.
Fine, yes, agreed. That’s all I’m saying too. (beat) So you’re still on board?
Look at me. I’m on board. Joe exhales, relieved. Patrick throws a bag of pork rinds Joe's pile.
These too.
Wow. You’re a class act.

MONTAGE. MUSIC CUE: “WHITE WINTER HYMNAL” by FLEET FOXES Joe plucks books from LIBRARY SHELVES. He stacks them on checkout counter: “WALDEN.” “105 OUTDOOR RECIPES.” “SO, Y WANT TO BUILD A CABIN.” Blueprints unroll. Reveal Joe, Patrick and Biaggio review them in an empty classroom. It feels like a war room. In the woods, Joe and Biaggio dump piles of timber next t Patrick, who ties them together with small vines. They ar symphony of sweat and grime. Joe and Biaggio watch as Patrick confidently bites into a herb. There’s an open reference book in Patrick’s hand. Joe stacks more books at the library counter: “SELF RELIA AND OTHER ESSAYS.” Then, the following comic books: “SPAW “BATMAN VS. PREDATOR,” “SUPERMAN: CAMELOT FALLS.” Then another reference book, “I'D RATHER BE HUNTING.” Patrick messes around with some dry twigs and flint, tryi to get a spark. Once he does, he blows on it - FIRE. On a suburban street, Biaggio halts his bike, seeing something. Swoosh pan to a sofa left on the curb as trash Biaggio and Joe set the sofa on a lumpy wood floor -- the house in the woods. One wall has been erected. On his stoop, Patrick picks leaves, twigs off his jeans a scatters them in the garden. He keeps an eye on the door.  32. Joe sits on the toilet, reading his Superman comic. Biaggio rides his bike through an affluent neighborhood. stops and looks off camera, in awe of something... Joe and Biaggio, guided by Patrick, carry an enormous POO SLIDE, ladder included. As the inch closer to the “house, we see that three walls have been erected, and there is m garbage furniture than before. It’s getting there. Joe emerges from a thick bit of trees and finds himself a a decent sized cliff, maybe seventy feet high. Out in fro of him, treetops stretch for miles. He inhales. END MONTAGE.
Joe and Patrick sit at an empty lunch table, drinking pla quarter drinks.
What are we gonna do about parents?
Well I’m not leaving a note or anything. I’m gonna let him stew in it for a while. Patrick makes a face, reacting to Joe’s harshness.
What happened in your house the other night anyway, man?

Nothing. He’s just...it’s like the chicken or the egg with my Dad. I don’t know if he’s alone because he’s a dick, or if he’s a dick because he’s alone. But either way he’s a dick. And he’s alone. He sighs.
It’s scary.
Yeah it is...what if I wound up like my Dad. Jesus -- what if I wound up like my Mom??  33.
She’s a strange bird.
I had a dream like maybe two days ago that she took a Polaroid of me on the toilet, and then ate it before it could develop.
Oof. I feel like that’s dense with meaning.
Yeah. Patrick chugs a purple quarter drink.
I had a dream that I could talk to reef sharks.
What did the sharks say?
They didn’t speak so much as rap. Joe drinks. Patrick gazes across the lunchroom.
(sentimental) I‘ll miss this stuff a little.
Yeah, a little. Joe's POV: A table across the room. A bunch of girls in matching T- shirts, part of the Spring Musical Committee. He’s focuse on one glittered face, laughing with her friends: Kelly.
To establish.

Patrick sits awake on his bed. On edge.  34. Then, his BEEPER goes off. He picks up a cordless phone. INT. JOE’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS Joe's beeper goes off. He silences it, then moves to his closet. He takes out two overstuffed DUFFEL BAGS. INT. PATRICK’S PARENTS’ ROOM - NIGHT Patrick watches his folks sleep. The house feels like a w safe place right now -- now that he’s leaving. He kisses his hand, and touches the door, but remains composed. His parents don’t stir. INT. JOE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Frank sleeps on the sofa, lit by blue light from the TV. Joe observes with narrow eyes.
Joe rides, weighed down by duffels and equipment. Patrick rides on the pegs, holding his own luggage. WIDE. They take in the ‘burbs for a final time. The stree are dimly lit, desolate.
Joe walks his bike into the woods, but Patrick stares bac the direction they came, hesitant.
You coming?
Yeah...This is happening, huh?
Yeah. It is. Patrick tries to articulate things.
I’ve never done anything like this in my entire life, man.  35.
(walks to his side) Sometimes when I’m about to make a big decision, I say “I will go through with this unless God gives me a very definite omen within the next 30 seconds.” We could do that.
Okay. Let’s do that. They stand silent for the agreed interval, each in his ow thoughts. Then, a clap of THUNDER. Patrick furrows a brow
Okay, time. Let’s go.
That’s thunder, Joe.
Yes, that’s thunder. (points at shit) That’s a tree, that’s a rock. It’s nature. It’s not an omen. He walks into the woods.
C’mon. Patrick steels himself.
Jesus. This is happening.
TORRENTIAL RAIN. The boys are soaked. The trees overhead can only do so much. They negotiate the path in silence. Patrick is not smilin

They walk in. Snippets of the house are revealed in FLASHLIGHT BEAMS. A piece of junky furniture...a portion makeshift wall...the water-slide in the room’s center...  36. INT. HOUSE IN THE WOODS, “UPSTAIRS” - NIGHT Darkness. Joe throws Patrick his used towel, then unrolls sleeping bag.
(drying off) Where's Biaggio?
I haven't heard from him in 3 days. But every instinct in my body tells me he’s already up here.
Get the fuck out of here. Gimme the flashlight.
You’re not gonna like the outcome of this. Patrick shines the flashlight around the room.
I feel like he’d be right next to you. Patrick turns the beam to his immediate left and, sure enough, Biaggio stares back at him, a ghastly figure. Patrick SCREAMS. Soundbridge to:
The MORNING BELL, over an establishing shot.
Series of shots in various classrooms: A) Spanish class. The teacher reads from an attendance bo
Lacertosa? (check) Laffin? (check) McGuire? Nothing. We see an empty seat.  37.
McGuire? B) History class.
Toy? Joe Toy? C) English.
Anyone hear from Joseph Toy? D) Concert Band.
Patrick McGuire here? McGuire? The teacher looks to an empty seat in the trombone sectio
Think you can handle first trombone today? A young trombonist slides into Patrick’s chair.
I think so, John.
Once again people, we do not call teachers by their first names. E) Health class.
Toy? H) Gym.

McGuire? (silence) Okay...Miller? (check) Moscato? Cut to Moscato raising his hand. He does have a weak chin A phone RINGS... INT. MCGUIRE HOUSE, BEDROOM --— DAY A hand shoots into frame; Mrs. McGuire’s.  38.
Hello?

Hello, parent of (human voice) -- “Patrick McGuire” -- this is Tottenville High School calling to inform that your child was absent from one or more scheduled classes, and will require a written note -- She hangs up. Reveal her laying in bed. It seems as thoug she’s been there a bit. The door opens. Mr. McGuire peeks in.
It was just the school.
Okay. If you want to come down...the police seem optimistic. She nods and rolls over, despondent.
Mr. McGuire at the table, sifting through photos of Patri with a PLAIN CLOTHES detective. Behind them, CAPTAIN ARTY DAVIS (50s) looks around.
Wrestler, huh?
Yes. A good one.
(delicate) Did you notice if Patrick had been running with any new friends? A different group than usual? Anyone give you a bad feeling?
No. He had good friends. He was popular, people liked him... He stares into space.  39.
My wife would know more about that. I don’t know if she...it’s just the shock of it.
Honestly, I see a lot of these, and you guys are doing great. You’re a tough bunch. Mr. McGuire tries to smile.
Thank you...it’s... (pause) He’s our only son, is the thing. He’s our only child, so...you’1l get him back?

We'll get him back. INT. JOE’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - NIGHT Frank, alone at the table. He rubs his finger around the edge of his glass of scotch, making a whistling sound. LISA’S VOICE Daddy? Frank moves to the doorway; Lisa and Colin walk through t storm door with some bags packed. She hugs him.
Shhh. It’s okay. I’m sure he’s fine. Colin awkwardly rubs her back. INT. JOE’S ROOM - LATER Frank & Lisa search Joe’s room, go through doors, check t closets.
We don’t know much. The thing is...(pause) Some things are missing. Things Joe might have planned to take. All his clothes. The Monopoly. The spare from the Avalon.
So...he ran away?
It’s still mostly guesswork, Li... But yes, it looks that way. Colin comes to the doorway.
The Chinese food is here, Mr. Toy. It's fifty-one dollars.
(digging into pocket) Fifty-one dollars? What did you order Lisa!?
Nothing. I got dumplings. I’m not hungry.
I got us a big order of shrimp with lobster sauce. I figured it’s neutral.
Neutral? Shrimp with lobster sauce? I can’t think of a more marginal dish in any culture.
I don’t know. I thought it was neutral. I thought we could all enjoy it.
Come on Colin, no one’s gonna eat that! Now there’s gonna be a pint of hot cum in my refrigerator for a week. Use your head next time. Colin takes the money and walks off.
Be nice to him, Dad. Please. He wants to help.
Colin’s feelings are not a priority right now. Sorry. 40.  4l.
I know...but you don’t have to be Mean, Daddy You just... Lisa assigns blame as gently as possible.
You don’t have to always be so mean. You know?
Am I mean to you?
No. But I’m like the only one, Dad. Frank contemplates this.

A few students pause to acknowledge... A MISSING CHILD poster. It’s a collage of three pictures: Patrick in his wrestling gear; Patrick posing with his parents in front of the globe at EPCOT; Patrick’s tastefu class photo. Off an image of Patrick’s INNOCENT FACE:
Patrick pulls his new, BEARDED face out of the fresh wate Reveal him sitting at the edge of a pond.

Patrick! He looks -- Joe and Biaggio stand on a high rock, holding tire attached to a rope. Joe has also grown wispy facial hair. Biaggio wears a swimming cap and underwear. Joe swings. He lets go at the top of his arc and cannonba into the water. As he emerges:
Ehhh...six.
(genuine disappointment) Six...Godammit.  Joe swings the tire back up to Biaggio.
Why does he have a swimming cap, but no bathing suit? 42. Biaggio clutches the tire and surveys the stream, nervous
(cups hands to mouth) Biaggio, just let go when you get to the top! It’s not even deep!
Look at this. He’s terrified.
I know. He once told me he’s only afraid of two things -- drowning, werewolves, very old music, and homeless women who can run or jump.
That’s four things.

I’m telling you exactly what he told me. Biaggio swings, all four limbs wrapped around the tire. At the top of his swing, he does nothing, paralzed with fear He swings back and forth, losing momentum.
What are you, a cat? Let go!
We're here Biaggio! We won't let the river claim you! Biaggio drops his legs. They enter the water at the knee. His hands are still fused to the tire. He hangs there.
Okay...we’re sort of in no man’s land here, Biaggio! Just make a decision! We want to use the tire!
Just untie it.  43.
Did you hear that, Biaggio? I’m giving you one more chance to do this on your terms! Biaggio lets go and falls awkwardly into the stream.
Six.
Bullshit!
Patrick stands in front of a beat-up mirror, shirtless... His hives are gone. He breathes deep, flexes, grins. He feels like himself. Then, ending his moment of serenity:
Yo. We have a food situation.

Joe gets downstairs via the WATER SLIDE from earlier. As walks through the house, we reveal it in its entirety: The water slide leads up to a “loft” area (just a huge le where the guys sleep. Downstairs, we recognize some garba furniture from earlier scenes -- a sofa, a lamp. There’s a dining room: an AIR HOCKEY TABLE. As Patrick and Joe approach this corner, Biaggio leans ov the table counting grains of rice.
(to Patrick) No more rice. And no more pasta. It’s time. Joe starts rummaging through a pile of supplies, emerging with a souvenir SWORD.
What kind of game are we dealing with?
Deer, pheasant, rabbit. You might run into a lynx.
Any bison? Cougar? Anything real?
You’re gonna kill a buffalo with a sword you got from a gift shop in Colonial Williamsburg?
It’s not the size of the blade, but the will of the swordsman.
(rolls eyes) You gotta stop with that elf shit, man. Joe re-sheathes his weapon.
Okay. Biaggio and I will hunt. You gather.
Then...here, take these. Patrick hands Joe and Biaggio small cardboard MASKS with crude FACES drawn on them in magic marker. Patrick wears his, but on the BACK OF HIS HEAD.
(pointing to it) It's so animals don’t pounce on you from behind.
(regarding masks) This one’s supposed to be me?
Whatever man. I wasn’t going for accuracy. Joe puts his on.  45.
So an animal will see this and think I’m looking at him, and walking backwards, and that all my joints are backwards.
It works, Joe. Nigerian bushmen have been doing it for centuries.
Right, Nigerian bushmen. And we all know how great they turned out.
What does that mean? Joe turns around with his mask on. Then he sticks his han out behind him, toward Patrick, as if offering a handshak
Hey, nice to meet you. I’m Joe.
Fuck yourself.
Wide shot, to establish.

Patrick holds open a field guide, checking the bunch of r berries before him against an illustration. He plucks them, bites into one for confirmation...then to the bunch into a bucket with other berries, roots, herbs.
Joe carries his sword, Biaggio his machete. They look lik little murderers.
I want to thank you for helping us, Biaggio. A lot of people would have just stayed in the comfort of their homes.  46.
This is life experience. Both my grandfathers went to war. My father lived among the bees. This is what I’1l have done.
Exactly! It’s our rite of passage, goddamit. (deep, satisfied breath) I mean have you ever felt this at one with the natural world, with your instincts? This masculine?
I don’t know. I don’t really see myself as “having a gender.” (then) Is that bad?

I mean, it’s not great. The boys duck through a thick, gnarly patch of brush... To find CIVILIZATION. The woods have ended. They stare at strip mall across the street. A BOSTON MARKET looms, the crown jewel of the shopping center.
(staring) Is it real?
Yes, it is... (then) Let’s go. We’re moving on. Biaggio is still entranced.
The 1/4 dark is very good, though.
Sure it is. You don’t think I know that? It falls off the goddam bone. But Boston Market, that’s not roughing it, that’s not living by our wits. That’s not the man’s code, the code of the forest.
One day, maybe.  47.
Yes, sure, one day. C’mon man, this was a test, and we passed. JOE'S POV: a B.M. employee throws garbage in a side dumps Close on Joe as he gets an idea.
Hmm...hold my weapon, Biaggio... Joe darts across the street. A moving car WIPES THE FRAME
A nearly-clean chicken skeleton falls to the ground.
Cut it right here. Reveal Joe and Biaggio rigging a TRAP: The chicken is tied to a stick, which props up an overtur WHEELBARROW. In theory, it should work.
Look at this bait, man. Biaggio looks at the chicken carcass. Flies buzz around i
Are there bears in these woods?
I hope to God there are. A bear would feed us for a month... Joe looks at the wheelbarrow.
He'd be too big for the trap...but I think we could at least disillusion him. A bear who doesn’t believe in anything is easier to bring down.
Have you ever eaten a bear steak?
(fiddling with the trap) No. You?  48.
Once. At my sister’s communion. Joe flicks the line.
Well it’s just a waiting game now, my friend.

Patrick shakes the shit out of an APPLE TREE. Granny smit rain down. He bends to pick one up, and something catches his eye... He grabs a twig and pokes at the ground, finally lifting very long, very appalling
He regards it with fear and revulsion. Then chucks it int the trees.
Joe and Biaggio play RUMMY, cards fanned out before them.
Sometimes I wonder, we bury fruit seeds, and new fruit grows. We bury what is left, and it’s reborn.
Right.
Could that not work with people? Bury the remains, the vital organs, and a new one might grow?
I don’t think it’s a bad theory, but we've been burying the dead for thousands of years, and that has never happened.
Hm; valid point. (then) Rummy.  49.
(inspecting) You only have five cards here. Sudden SOUNDS OF A STRUGGLE from the woods behind them. T trap is sprung.
Shit! Yes! Come on!
We hear awful SCRATCHING and SQUEALING from inside. They approach, sick with fear.
(sword at the ready) Okay, turn the thing.
Turn the thing...
Yeah just turn the wheelbarrow. Just, you know..flip it, and I, uh, will take its life.
Okay. (moves to wheelbarrow) Strike at the neck. Don’t compromise the meat.
I know...I know... Biaggio puts his hands on the wheelbarrow.
You want this on your hands?
What choice do we have?! We need to eat goddammit...
It may plead. Don’t listen. Be cold, clinical with the blade.
Okay, okay.  50.
It may try to bargain. This is natural. You must--
Turn the fucking thing over! He does: A huge pink and white POSSUM, likely rabid, hiss at Joe. The boys SCREAM. INSERT: Wide above the forest. Their screams echo.

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, FIRE PIT

text: Three whole roasted chickens sizzle on a SPIT, pulled ove crackling fire.
I guess I’m surprised you found live chicken in these woods.
Why should that be surprising? Chicken outnumber people in this world. You’re an educated guy, I don’t need to tell you that.
Yeah, I just had never seen one in Staten Island, New York before.
Well that’s crazy. There was a time when you hadn’t seen me yet, right? Did that mean I didn’t exist?
I don’t even know what the fuck we're talking about any more.
It doesn’t matter. Biaggio, your creamed spinach is to die for. Biaggio nods.
You guys should know I found a copperhead skin by the creek. It definitely belonged to a mature adult. In the event--  51.
C’mon man. We’re having a nice meal.
This is important Joe!
There’s always something with you. Some doom and gloom.
It’s not doom and gloom, Joe, it’s the reality of living in the goddam forest, which was your idea to begin with.
The thing...it has venom?
Yes. Listen -- (to both) If you see it, stay calm. They respond to fear.
I read once that animals see fear as a color.
I thought you couldn’t read?
I can read. I can’t cry.
Joe and Patrick sit on rocks, looking out.
Doesn’t suck, does it.
No. No it doesn’t. Reverse to their POV: Trees. Stars. Peaceful. (We might remember this view from the earlier montage) Joe flips his BACKPACK around and unzips it.  52.
I was saving these... He removes a SIX PACK.
For the right moment.
(happily accepting) No shit.
Yes shit. They clank bottles and drink. Their first beer together.
Ah...Do you feel it?
Feel what.
We’re doing it, man. We have shelter, water, the means to put food on the table. We’re totally self-reliant. We just grew up. (then) We're men now. Men.
Just now? It just happened?
It happened man. Cheers. Joe takes another pull. Patrick shakes his head, bemused.
Now all we need is the Ham.
What’s the ‘ham?’
The Ham. You know, the Ham -- the pussy.
No, I don’t know “the ham, the pussy.” Where the fuck did you get that from?  53.
It’s in the culture.
We're in the same culture. I’ve never heard that.
The Ham! We takin’ a ride in the HAMbulance, to HAMsterdam! Uh!
Are you done?

I am. (swig) I’m just saying, if something were missing from this, that would be it. (then) A woman’s touch. He drinks, suddenly distant. We know who he’s thinking about... He hears a sqeak, and notices a SQUIRREL peering at him. reaches into his coat and tosses it a NUT, or some tasty morsel. It grabs the nut and takes off.
The squirrel runs with its prize, over rocks and roots. I pauses at the base of a tree and begins to nibble. Suddenly, we hear HISSING, and the rustling of leaves. It freezes...and turns to look.

A half-million dollar home. Chrysler New Yorker in the driveway. Basketball hoop out front. Frank stares at it, chewing gum nervously. He’s shaven, pressed, more put together than we’ve ever seen. He takes a deep breath, and goes halfway up the walk...th doubles back toward his car.  54.
He starts the engine. Then kills it.
(to himself) Fuck you! Pussy.
He rings the bell. Waits. An attractive, middle-aged brunette answers. She’s taken aback to see Frank there.
Clarissa. INT. CLARISSA’S KITCHEN - DAY They sit over coffee. Opposite sides of the table.
Had you guys been fighting?
He called 911 over a Monopoly game.
See, I don’t like that. That’s a regression. Twin 19 year-olds, JOSH and JAKE, enter and raid the frid
Ma, Denise is coming over later.
Fine. Just clean the basement. Without provocation, Jake backhands his brother in the crotch. Josh doubles over, mostly in shock.
Dick'd ya!
Oh! Dick’d ya! Josh chases Jake into the living room. Clarissa sighs.  55.
I guess they don’t know.
No, they know. (then) So, what? The police came?
Yeah, but it doesn’t...I mean, all we do is fight, Clarissa.
Boys and their fathers clash, Frank. It’s normal. (then) You didn’t get along with your father for decades, right? And now you love and respect him dearly.
Yeah, because he’s dead. (takes a sip) Joe wasn’t always like this. This angry, this moody. Frank stirs his drink. Uncomfortable silence.
If you try to put this on me, the conversation is over.
I’m not putting anything on you. I’m just saying. He’s difficult.
Every teenager is moody.
Yeah. One time we had a fight over his grades. He told me my mother “sucked cocks in hell.”
He did not say that.
Verbatim.
Hm...it’s from The Exorcist though. It’s not his original thought.  56.
I think we can agree it’s not the number one thing to say about your grandmother. Silence. She can’t argue that.
I’m gonna say something, because it has to be said. And you have to hear it. (then) I think if you came back, Joe would too. There it is. Clarissa nods.
Frank stands facing the door, as it slams. He stands ther for a beat.
School’s out. AARON waves goodbye to some friends, and breaks away. He walks alone down the a street behind the school bleachers. The other side of the street is woods.
Joe’s POV: Aaron, through trees.
Psst! No response.

Psssst! Aaron keeps walking, content in whatever he’s thinking ab Joe picks up a rock and chucks it without aiming. It hits Aaron just above the eye and ricochets out of frame. Aaron moans and drops to one knee. He looks around, confu and in pain, putting up a desperate hand to ward off furt attacks.  57.
shit. He checks the street -- empty. Then runs toward Aaron.
Aaron, staring at it, awed. Joe smiles, pleased.
No fucking way. Patrick emerges from the house, big grin.
Hal Aaron and Patrick exchange a huggy, slappy, greeting.
Aaron pokes and prods at the housewares, fascinated. Biag sits at a barrel, sorting berries by color. Patrick watch over his shoulder.
Make yourself at home, man. You thirsty? Hungry? Joe reaches for the apple bowl, tosses one to Aaron.
Joe...how did you do this? How long did it take?

About ten days. It’s a pretty simple structure. The roof is plywood, it just rests there...you could flap it open if you wanted to...I handled schematics...Patrick bound most of the walls together... Joe looks around. A moment of pride for the accomplishmen
Anyway, it’s a start. Eventually we'll add to it. We’re just still getting used to the family dynamic. But we have ideas for the place. We've talked about a garden. (MORE )
I know Biaggio desperately wants a dog.
It’s all I dream about.
Yes, but why do you want a dog? Biaggio looks down.
See, he can’t answer that. That’s what troubles us.
Aaron follows Joe down a path.
I need a ride to Thirsty Thursdays tonight. Can you take me?
My brother's driving. But yeah.
Your brother? I thought he was like nineteen.
He was when you met him, yes.
He won’t make me out, will he?
Please. My brother’s a fucking idiot. He couldn’t find his asshole with his finger. (then) Not that he’d want to. Not that anyone would.
Whatever. I’11l be there. I have to talk to Kelly.
Shit man -- she came up to me last week asking if I had heard anything about you guys. It honestly looked like she was crying. (MORE )
Like she had just finished. She was flush about the cheeks. And her very tasteful mascara was a little runny. Joe processes the information. This shit is on.
I’1l be outside the Greenville Boston Market. Do not forget. INT. AARON’S KITCHEN - EVENING Aaron sits at dinner with his brother ERIC, 23, a young m with no sideburns. Aaron’s MOM is at the stove.
Eric, can you give one of my friends a ride to Wolf's?
If he got gas money. (to their mother) Where’s meat? AARON’S MOM This is beef stew. It’s a specific type of meat. What have I said about speaking in generalities?

Fine. (looking around) When’s man coming home? AARON’S MOM Your father is in Atlantic City. He is also a very specific type of man, he is your Fa-Ther. Aaron’s mom brings over a cauldron of beef stew. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) Now this is piping, piping hot, alright? Don’t touch it for a good ten minutes. Eric immediately ladles a heaping portion into his plate.  60. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) I’m not kidding, Eric. I know you’re hungry, but look at it. It’s still boiling. Eric takes a bite and instantly spits it back into his pl with a wet THUD. He exhales, and then lifts the food to h mouth again. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) Fine. Burn your mouth for Easter.

Joe wears a hooded sweatshirt, a hat, shades. He paces, fidgets. Like a wanted man. Then, the sound of speakers rattling with too much bass. turns to see an ancient two-door CAMARO pull into the par lot. This is Eric’s princess.

Joe and Aaron in back, Eric and some guido friend up fron Obnoxious TECHNO music plays. Deafening. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK - NIGHT They walk down a path, walled in by tall grass. Distant sounds of a party, and faint orange firelight. Joe and Aa lag behind the older guys.
What if someone recognizes you?

If anyone makes eye contact with me, I’m gone. If they ask you, deny everything. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK, BEACH - NIGHT They're at “Thirsty Thursdays,” a raging, lively keg. Mus a bonfire, a huge keg line, teenagers grinding up on each other. Fun. Joe walks along the outer edge of the general party area, keeping his head low, but taking it in. Shit, if his life had been anything like this...  61.
Kelly’s goth pal VICKI comes down from a keg-stand. The guys holding her legs turn out to be Eric and his friend. Vicki looks at Eric, who smiles like a creep.
Jesus.

Joe hides behind someone’s pickup, scanning the scene...s no sign of Kelly. Suddenly he hears a SCREAM from behind him: And there she is, by the water. She’s surrounded by dudes with backwards hats. One of the guys has her around the waist. They toss her, screaming, into the bay. Laughter. She emerges, yelling and splashing at them. Tight on Joe. Suddenly, two hands land on Joe’s shoulders and whip him around. A BLONDE KID is staring him in the face.
Dude! Where you been?? He pulls the hood down, revealing Joe’s face. Joe’s eyes dart around, but he’s trying to keep it cool.
Oh, you’re not Doug. Sorry bro.
Uh, it’s okay. All good. The kid stumbles away, wasted.
Yeah man. My fault. Nice face though... Joe turns to look at himself in the car window, and wince Unkempt, wispy beard. General filthiness.
Shit. A hand reaches for the car door he’s standing in front of He turns to see a dripping-wet Kelly.  62.

Excuse me. (eyes widen, realizing) OhmyGod!! Joe covers her mouth. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK, PLAYGROUND - NIGHT Joe and Kelly alone, on a SEESAW. We hear party sounds in the distance, and lapping waves.
But why not like, run away to California?
This was the only way to start fresh on our own terms. We answer to no one. We don’t need a larger social structure to be happy.
(laughing) Oh my God! You went insane!
Or we're the only sane ones.
Well either way. I wouldn’t have the guts to do it. Joe beams at the compliment. Kelly takes a drink from her big red solo cup.
So, um...can I see it?
I mean, that’s funny. The reason I’m out here, risking the entire enterprise, was to invite you over for dinner. If you want.
Obviously “I want.” How do I get there? Do I have to be blindfolded?  She makes 63.

I’m not sure yet. And it is of absolute vital importance that you not tell anyone, not bring anyone, not breathe a word of this conversation or any ensuing events, to anyone, no best friends, no family. No one.
Okay. Can I bring Vicki?
(beat) Fine. Just Vicki.
Oh my God. So much fun. Does Patrick have a big crazy beard too?
Yeah, a little more serious than this one. I have thin hair. A gift and a curse.
Facial hair is very sexy. You just gotta, you know, groom it.
Right, like Paul. a face.
What?
I guess you wouldn’t have heard... Paul and I broke up.
No, I didn’t get wind of it. It’s not big news among the badgers. (then) I’m sorry, though. Are you okay?
(bemused) Yes, I’m very okay. Thank you. A silhouetted figure calls to them, backlit by headlights  64. KID’S VOICE Yo Kel! We’re leaving!
Shit. Okay. When am I coming?
Saturday. KID’S VOICE (walking toward them) Who is that?!
(panic) I’m out of here.
Go! I’1l see you Saturday.
Bring your appetite. And some insect repellent. (running off) Oh, hey -- yellow is your favorite color, right?
Yes...why? But he’s gone.
Patrick walks outside, groggy.
Joe?

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, FIRE PIT

text: Patrick brushes his teeth with boiled water from the pot, over the fire. He looks up, and notices Biaggio, about twenty yards away, clinging to a tree, perfectly still. He stares at Patrick. He is covered with mud, leaves and branches, trying to be camouflaged.
Biaggio. No response. Patrick moves toward him.  65.
Yo. I see you man. He’s now a foot from Biaggio’s face. Biaggio won’t break.
Hello! I fucking see you! I’m looking in your eyes! Biaggio stares back unfazed, at one with the tree.
Dickhead! Fed up, he pushes Biaggio off the tree..
Oh, hey. What’s up?
(rolls eyes) Yeah, “hey.” Where’s Joe?

Joe picks yellow flowers in a vast meadow. Joe, half submerged in a stream, trims his facial hair. Joe lays out clothing options. There are three shorts-and T-shirt combinations. All are stained and grimy. “Upstairs,” Joe unrolls a blanket, revealing small safe deposit box. He unlocks it and removes a wad of PETTY CAS
Joe, and his new MOUSTACHE, sets the table with hot Bosto Market Chicken.
(from doorway) Such hypocrisy.
What? This is a special occasion.  66.
Bullshit man. How much chicken have you bought since we got here??
Huh? I mean, maybe one or two along the way. Biaggio and I have been pretty goddam dangerous out there.
(sigh) I can live with the chicken being store-bought, but I’m disappointed in the loaded potato. I thought that was really Biaggio’s recipe.
That actually really is. I have no idea where he’s getting chives. Patrick looks at Joe’s moustache.
And I’d lose that thing as well.
What? (realizing) Nope. This is who I am now.
You look fucking weird, man. You look like one of those kids who works in the student Shop Rite.
You don’t know what you’re talking about. The moustache is the real man’s choice. It’s a companion.
It’s not a real moustache. It’s all stringy and pervy.
Give it some time.
(staring at it) You look like that kid Mike Mancuso.  67.
Mancuso? He’s a good guy.
He brought a flare gun to school in January. Remember that?
What do you want me to tell you? January’s tough on some people.
Seriously, shave the moustache.
No.

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, FIRE PIT

text: Joe staring into the fire. The wavy heat lines gliss to:
Crane down from an immaculate sunset. Joe and Kelly watch wearing huge, flowing, Arthurian robes. Flower pedals fal from the sky. A land of kings and wizards.
How do you like it here?
This is the happiest I’ve ever been, Joe. But... (looks at him) Are we too young to know what love is?
I know. I’m afraid of that too. But we can be afraid together. He leans in to kiss her, when:
Kelly. They turn - Paul waits by edge of the trees. He looks haggard, crazed.
Time to come home.  68.
I am home.
Cut the shit, babe! You’re fifteen, I’m seventeen. Time to settle down.
Not with you, Ju’tuun. Never with you. She clutches Joe’s arm.
Don’t tell me. This? This...boy??
He’s more man than you’ll ever be. End this, Joe.

“End this”...are you sure you know what you're asking? She nods. Then, Paul unsheathes two large, wrought-iron hookswords CHARGES. In one fluid motion, Joe jumpkicks Kelly out of way, and slices a ROPE running along the floor. Joe then rolls, as we see a huge LOG, hanging by a thick rope, swi out from the trees behind them. Paul turns -- it hits him in the chest, obliterating him the cliff. He bounces a few times along the rocky face, a then slides to a halt, dead. Joe and Kelly peer down at him. She begins to cry gently.
You would weep for him?
Only for youth...only for youth. Some weasels approach the corpse and begin to pick at it.
The animals will take his eyes...denying his entry into Paradise... He kisses her forehead, then stares across the treetops, reflecting on the fragile nature of life.  69.
Joe! As Joe turns around:

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, FIRE PIT

text: Joe snaps out of it, turning to face Patrick.
We have company. Aaron, Vicki and Kelly emerge from the trail behind him.
Kelly in the doorway, seeing everything for the first tim
Are you kidding me right now? From Kelly’s POV: The slide, the hockey table, the loft. waits nervously for her judgment. Then:
This is great, Joe! On Joe’s face. Life is good.

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, DINNER TABLE

text: A Boston Market feast. The sunflowers Joe picked sit in t center of the table.
I like your beard, Patrick! You look like a werewolf.
(quick, to Vicki) Watch your mouth.
What did you guys do with this chicken? Garlic? Oil? Rosemary?
Biaggio?  70.
Thyme. Garlic and oil. Lotta pepper. Patrick rolls his eyes.
It melts. You don’t need a knife.
What do you guys eat most of the time? This?
Yeah. There are a lot of chicken in these woods, apparently.
Patrick takes care of berries, grains, herbs.
Ha. You’re like an Australopithecus woman.
Sure.
I handle meats, proteins. I usually do the hunting.
(quiet) And the shopping. Joe glares at him. Patrick smiles, mouth full, loving it.
What do you do, Biaggio?
Biaggio’s a renaissance man. He belongs out here. And such quick hands. He can snatch trout right out of the creek.
Bullshit.
It’s true man. I’ve seen it.  71. Biaggio slides something across the table to Aaron: a wal Aaron checks the inside; it’s his.
Did you take anything out?
He doesn’t want your money. He does it for sport. Joe notices Kelly eyeing the flowers. Good. She points at them.
Aaron, can you pass me the corn? Aaron complies, handing them to her over the flowers. Joe registers the slightest disappointment.
Joe and Kelly. She points at a wall: half a rotten fish skeleton nailed above a calendar. Beneath that, an old wi legged stool.
What’s this supposed to be?
This is the den.
Ha. How stupid of me. Did you catch this fish yourself?
We found it whole, floating in the swamp. I bet Biaggio he couldn’t eat the whole thing, and it turns out I was right.
Sexy. (points upstairs) And that’s the master bedroom?
Yeah. We need the slide because of shit-leg over there. At the table, Patrick inspects the chicken skeleton for m meat.  72. Joe uses this lull to gather the necessary courage.
There’s also a pretty cool sort of lookout you might like. I dunno. It's sort of splendid. Did I just say “splendid”?
(laughs) Yes, you did. A lookout?
Yeah...we could go check it out of your want. It’s like a fifteen minute hike, maybe.
Oh, yeah I want to see everything. But look at this -- I can’t leave Vicki alone with these jackals.

Oh, yeah, no. Of course not. INT. HOUSE IN THE WOODS, ‘LIVING ROOM’ - NIGHT Everyone sits on couch cushions that have been tossed on floor. Beers are out. A joint makes the rounds. Some of them wear Patrick’s ridiculous Nigerian bushmen MASKS. They're watching Biaggio, who break dances in the middle the room to “Breathe,” by Prodigy. Biaggio is killing it he’s actually a brilliant dancer. He too wears a mask. Applause. Kelly passes the joint to Patrick.
I’m good.
Gotcha. (all smiles) No weed, but you’ll run away from home. Very contradictory.
Well, I go back twice a week to do laundry. She smiles.  73.
(holding arm up) I have a beer, see? I’m dangerous.
A full beer. She clanks bottles with him and starts chugging. He does same, catching Joe’s glance across the floor. Patrick rol his eyes, like “women.” Joe fakes a smile.
One side of the fire, Aaron and Vicki. On another, Patric and Kelly. Joe and Biaggio are off to the side, speaking private.
Vicki is making eyes at you. You should go talk to her.
No. I think she likes Aaron.
I doubt it. Aaron’s bizarre. I feel like he has no asshole or something. Like a Conehead.
Well, there’s no point in me talking to her anyway. Biaggio looks down.
What’s wrong?
(a struggle for him) Joe...I’m gay. Joe is taken aback.
Jesus...are you sure, man?
Yes. My lungs fill up with fluid every time the seasons change. Joe thinks about how to put this.  74.
That’s not being gay...I think that means you have cystic fibrosis.
Really? (relief) Thank you.
Yeah. (then) Cystic fibrosis is no walk in the park, Biaggio. Biaggio waves him off, unworried.
What about her? Joe's POV: Kelly and Patrick, firelit, talking and laughi
She’s doing what girls do. Acting like she doesn’t care. It’s fine. I can wait. Biaggio leaves to talk to Vicki. Joe watches Kelly, who never looks in his direction.
Downstairs, a tangle of limbs on the floor. And the couch In the dark, we can’t really tell who’s sleeping where.

Joe lies on his side, covers pulled high. The light is di but we see he’s awake. Creaking from downstairs. The top of the ladder shakes. H stares at it...hands, then arms come into view. Then the face. It’s Kelly. She walks toward Joe. His eyes widen as... She carefully steps over him, and shakes Patrick awake. W don't leave Joe’s face during this next exchange.
(whisper) Hey...can you sleep?  75.
Um, yes. We hear her hushed laughter.
Do you want to take a walk or something? I can’t sleep.
(pause) Sure. We hear rustling; Patrick rises. Tight on Joe. Unblinking EXT. WOODS —- MORNING Wide, expansive. Establish a new day.
Beams of light slice through the loft. Joe lies in the sa position, wearing the same expression. We hear voices from downstairs. VICKI’S VOICE Is he still sleeping?
Joe! Joe doesn’t respond. The ladder rattles; Kelly peeks over the landing. Joe quickly shuts his eyes.
(whisper) Joe. We’re leaving. Are you awake? Joe keeps his eyes closed.
Kelly stands at the edge of the clearing, where the trail begins. Patrick hands her a girlish duffel bag.
So did Biaggio tell you about “Omerta”?  76.
Omerta, yes. The Sicilian code of silence. Don’t worry, we all swore. He made Aaron cut his palm.
Good. Well, you know the way so +..you can come back anytime.
Thanks. So can you. They both smile.
A car pulls into the driveway...illuminating FRANK on the stoop. Mr. McGuire gets out of the car.
(emotionless) Frank.
Daniel. Listen, I -- Mr. McGuire punches Frank in the face. Frank goes down.
Nice parenting, you cooze! They roll around on the lawn, fighting. Mrs. McGuire come to the door.
No no no! Nooooo-- Off her howls of protest:
The McGuires sit on their couch, opposite Frank. Frank ho an ice pack to his eye. Mr. McGuire has a scratch mark on his cheek, and a fat lip.
I’m not here to apologize for my son.  77.
And you shouldn’t. We don’t even know - for sure - that they ran away. We do not know. All anyone can do is suspect things. Suspect suspect suspect.
The police have presented a lot of evidence, honey. They’re certain. We have to trust them.
Well what do the police know! With their pig Irish agenda. The Irish are the blacks of Europe! The blacks of Europe!
(rubbing her back) Shhhhh...come on. I’m Irish, sweetheart. (then) This has been hard on her, Frank.

And I don’t want to take up more of your time. Trust me. I know this is awkward. I just... (pause) I noticed you put some fliers of Patrick around school, around the neighborhood. I asked the police if I should do that with Joe, if that would be helpful, and they said it couldn’t hurt. So I was just going to ask you if you had some pictures of Joseph. If there were shots of him and Patrick together, whatever. Some recent stuff. You’d be doing me a favor. Silence for a moment.
Oh. I’11 look. We have...hold on.

She hands Frank about five pictures. Frank thumbs through them.  78. Joe and Patrick on a back porch, drying off, a pool in th background. At Medieval Times, wearing hats. Covered in shaving cream on Halloween. Frank is transfixed by them.
Thank you.

The SUN. We’re looking straight up at it. Joe lies, squinting, in the same meadow where he picked t flowers for dinner. Utter silence. He twirls a dandelion in his hand... Then grinds the flowerhead between the meaty parts of his thumb and forefinger. Joe sits up. We see that the meadow is expansive, beautif Tall yellow flowers stretch far into the distance. He sha his brow with his hand, looking around.
(shouts loudly) Biaggio!? Nothing. He shades his brow, looking for any sign of Biaggio. Then, less than five feet from him, Biaggio emerges, maki Joe jump.
Jesus. Biaggio, when you’re here, keep your head above the surface where I can see you. (rises) I’m going for a walk. Don’t wait up.
You should try not to think about them so much. Joe hangs his head.
I’m sorry I’m not more fun to be around right now.  79.
Let’s do something fun. You need it. Let’s make fresh jam.
I don’t want to make fresh jam, Biaggio. I just want to be alone. Sorry.
Or we could even do that other thing. The thing we talked about.
I’m not letting you give me a haircut.
Joe hikes uphill, holding a brown bottle. A ring of sweat around his collar. He pushes through brush, accessing...
But finds Patrick and Kelly there. Awkward. Joe fakes a friendly smile.
Oh, hey Joe, I--
Whoops. No nono nono. Stay here. Do your thing. I’m gonna head back by the house.
What is that? Are you drunk?
(waving his hands) Do your thing. Do your thing. I’‘1l see you kids later. Joe leaves. Kelly gets up, but Patrick stops her.
I got it...  80.
Joe walks off, no longer smiling, his face red and flush. From behind him:
Joe. Joe, wait up.
(smiling again) What’s up? Why’d you leave her? Go back.
Joe...look man. Nothing’s going on, okay?
It’s fine. You win. The best man won.
What does that mean? She just likes me. We get along.
Cool. I guess she likes everyone though. So I mean, if she likes everyone, she likes no one. You know? Patrick snatches the bottle from Joe.
What the fuck is this shit... Arizona Iced Tea? You're sober, Joe. Why are you acting like a weird lawyer or something?
You’re so young. (then) Listen, if you and your girlfriend want, come over later for dinner and a board game. Okay?
“Come over”?
If you want. Biaggio will be there too. Good times, good times.  81. Joe stumbles off. Patrick stares after him, bewildered.
Patrick and Kelly sit, facing each other.
We’re not doing anything wrong.
I know. Patrick looks down, futzing around with a twig, thinking.
Do you want to...do something wrong?
Very much so. He chucks the twig over the cliff. She approaches and sit in his lap. He puts his arms around her. He’s easily twic her size. They look in the same direction, over the trees
So did it work?
Did what work?
This. The house. Are you happier out here?
I mean...I’m just happy to be where my parents are not.
They can’t be that bad. I mean what did they do, anyway? Everyone at school thinks they were like molesting the shit out of you.
(laughs) “Molesting the shit out of me”? No no. I would have stayed for that. (she laughs) No...it was nothing that sinister.  82. He thinks about it.

They weren’t bad people, they were just always...there. Down my throat, all day, every day. Constant and unyielding. I was getting hives. The top of my head would tingle. I thought I was gonna have a heart attack.
So, they were down your throat... like everybody else’s parents.
No, “not like everybody else’s.” I do not accept that.
(laughing) Everybody else’s.
I’m fourteen. My mom offered to cut my nails six months ago. She sits up, facing him.

Every single morning, my parents set out three dollars and twenty- five cents. The three dollars is for lunch. The twenty five cents is so I can call and tell them I got to school okay. (beat) And I’m fifteen.
They watch me eat. Sometimes they don’t say anything. They get pleasure out of it.
They watch me sleep. Like serial killers. I wake up, and they’1l be standing at the doorway. Patrick laughs.  83.
That's just parents, Patrick. All of them. You have to, like, humor them and get on with your day.
Maybe. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE - DAY Colin packs luggage into his trunk while Frank and Lisa s goodbye. The car idles.
Call me with anything, Dad. Even if it’s bad.
I will. Go to school, get drunk with your friends, do whatever. And you can call me too, you know. They hug. Colin turns and approaches for a goodbye. Frank waves coolly.

Take it easy, Colin. Colin goes in for a handshake, but Frank has already wave Colin quickly retracts, waving, but by then Frank has lea in for a handshake. After a few missed signals, Frank sig grabs Colin’s hand and shakes it.

Jesus. It never ends with you. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Frank waves as the car pulls away. The car hits the corne and a group of teens, around Joe’s age, ride bikes down t street. Whipping past Frank’s house. Frank watches them g
He clicks on the TV, the stereo. Noise fills the atmosphe
Moonlit. An OWL leaves its perch, gliding over Bringing us to a wide shot of the HOUSE.
A small thimble lands on CHANCE. Kelly reads a and Patrick face Joe and Biaggio. They all sit
Ooh -- advance to Indiana. I’1l buy that. Biaggio smashes the floor in anger. He and Joe
Easy does it. (to them) He likes the red.
The color of blood. The color of passion.
(to Kelly) I’‘1l give you B&O for both your utilities.
Really? Okay.
And your Get Out of Jail Free card.
Yeah...but if I need it, can I have it back?
Yes, you can have it back.
That’s a smart trade.
Huh?
All four railroads for the utilities. Saavy. 84. the trees. card. She on the floor. smoke CIGARS.  85.
And a Get Out of Jail Free card. Joe rolls his eyes.
Just play your game. Don’t worry about us. Tense beat between Joe and Patrick. Kelly’s eyes shift between the friends.
...Are you two alright?
(polite smile) We're golden. (rolls die) Monkey. Joe moves his piece to FREE PARKING. Biaggio claps.
Good job, Joe.
He didn’t do anything. It’s dice.
I’m gonna put one more house on... Joe stops and looks at the board.
Actually...Biaggio, I will give you Park Place and Baltic, and both my railroads, for both your oranges. Biaggio thinks about it.
I want a thousand dollars.
I will give you...a hundred fifty.
Yahtzee. They trade. Patrick shakes his head. This is catastrophic  86.
(to Patrick) Property manager, can I get hotels on orange?

You just gave him the corner, dickhead. What’s the matter with you? Patrick puts the hotel on orange...then pauses. He looks his own piece. He’s in jail. A roll away from the oranges Patrick looks at Joe.
What’s up, Joe?
Nothing’s up. (big smile) It’s your roll, Tum Tum.
Joe, if I roll a six, eight or nine it’s gonna get very bad in here.
(looking at board) Oh...yeah.
Well, I don’t know what to tell you. Think of all the other numbers in the world. Joe leans back and exhales cigar smoke. A woodland Bugsy.
Well let’s just take a minute and relax. It’s a game, right?
I’m relaxed. Biaggio? Biaggio nods, gagging on cigar smoke.
What’s your fucking problem, man??
Just roll, Patrick. Don’t let it get to you. You'll be fine.  87. A tense moment of silence. Patrick rolls.
Wide. A beat of nothing...then, the monopoly board flies the window.
Joe retreats to the corner. Patrick is trying to move tow him, as Kelly tugs his arm.
I have a cigar! Be careful! This whole place is dry wood!
Give a fuck, man! What was that play!?
Jesus! It. Is. A. Game!
What I did was completely legal! Patrick takes a step at Joe, but Kelly steps between them
You guys, stop! Biaggio’s having some sort of episode! Biaggio sits rocking in the corner.
Leave him. He’s rationalizing.
(to Joe) That was the lowest, shittiest, dickhead move I’ve ever seen.
Eh -- second lowest. Patrick pauses, marveling at Joe’s pettiness.
Fuck. You. No one was trying to hurt you, man. It had nothing to do with you. Get over it!  88.
I’m fucking over it! I don’t care! If the bitch wants you, she’s not good enough for me anyway.
What? Huh?? Who the fuck are you, Mary J. Blige??
Joe, I didn’t--
No, Kelly! Everything was fine until you got here. Jesus! You're like a fucking cancer. Kelly is completely stunned. Hurt. Her eyes well up.
Okay. Um, I guess I’ll see you guys later... And just like that...she leaves. Patrick watches.
(hurt, confused) What are you doing, Joe?
Go ahead. Go be with her.
I don’t want to go, Joe. Joe pushes him. Patrick doesn’t budge.
Get out of here! Go hang out with Kelly and your goddam mother! Joe keeps pushing him. Patrick stands his ground.
(heartbroken) What...Why are you doing this, man? Then, rage and frustration at their peak, Joe KICKS Patri bad foot. This gets a reaction.
Ah! Fuck!  89. Patrick’s face darkens. Joe comes to his senses - he just poked the bear.

Shit. Patrick raises his hand to punch Joe, but resists the urg he'd kill him. He turns, channeling his rage toward the A HOCKEY TABLE. He chucks it, roaring, in Joe’s general direction. It hits the WEST WALL and topples it. Leaves a dirt kick up, blowing into the house. Joe watches, his chest heaving with anger, panic. Then he turns to Patrick. They look at each other. Silence. There has never been such darkness between them. Finally, inevitably...Patrick moves to the door. Joe watc him leave. It’s over. Biaggio approaches Joe, meek.
Just leave me alone, please.
What do you mean?
I’m saying leave. Get out of the house.
Be straight with me, Joe. Tell me what’s on your mind Joe.
I want to be alone, Biaggio. Get the fuck out.
Don’t mince words with me, Joe. We've been through too much. Joe looks him in the eye.
Biaggio walks out in a wide shot. His head hangs.  90.
Joe sits on the sofa, back to the downed wall, taking in ruin of his house.

Various shots of Patrick, struggling on his bad foot, thr brush and over huge, gangly roots. He uses a large branch a WALKING STICK. He sits on a rock, massaging his lower leg. Angry. Sad. It's all hitting him.
Fucking Joe. Asshole. Suddenly, we hear a RUSTLE. Patrick looks up.
Hello? Nothing.
Is someone there? Kelly? A shadowy figure wipes across the foreground. We can’t ma it out.

Biaggio, you're smarter than this. We hear a GRUNT. It’s not Biaggio. Patrick rises, moving down the path as quickly as his bum foot will allow. Then, a TUFT OF ORANGE HAIR catches his eye. What is happening? Patrick limps faster now, panicking, out of breath. A snarling ROAR.

(to himself) Oh fuck. God. Jesus. FOOTSTEPS. Whatever it is, it’s getting closer. Patrick STUMBLES on a root, and falls against a tree. He turns, hiding behind it.  91. Patrick takes his sneaker off, jamming the walking stick inside it to simulate a leg. He sticks it out into the pa as bait. Nothing bites. Silence. He turns to look at the path. It’s empty. As he doubles back behind the tree: We reveal a huge, green 2-D computer-animated monster -- BLANKA from “Street Fighter.” Standing on hind legs, it ROARS 3 TIMES in Patrick’s face Patrick SCREAMS and, instinctively, SMASHES BLANKA IN THE FACE with his walking stick. Upon impact, Blanka transforms into what he actually is - small tree with a shock of red-orange leaves at the top. Patrick has cracked it in half.
Huh. He stares at it, his head cocked. He blinks. Just a tree. Nothing scary about it.
Kelly, walking on a dark street. Alone. Unhappy. We hear the clacking of her shoes. Then from behind her:
Kelly! She stops. He limps/runs toward her, catching up. They stand face to face for a beat.
(blurting) I didn't want any of this to happen I don’t want to come between friends I've just liked you for months and I figured if I came out here and we got to-- He kisses her. She returns it.  92.
Joe tries to lift the fallen wall. He’s not strong enough He gives up, looks at it, rubs his shoulder.
Joe picks bits of meat from a clean chicken skeleton.

Frank opens the refrigerator door. The only option: lefto shrimp with lobster sauce. Christ knows how old it is. Quick cuts: He picks the shrimp out and places them over some white r Pops the bowl in the microwave. Eats in front of the television. INT. FRANK’S ROOM - NIGHT Frank, alone in a king-size bed, staring at the ceiling.
Joe pulls the sheets up to his chin. He rolls over, tryin to get comfortable. Sounds of the forest occasionally startle him.

Extreme wide. The house, a small and vulnerable structure the huge, dark forest. INT. PATRICK’S ROOM - MORNING Patrick wakes up. In his own bed. He rolls over: His parents are watching from the doorway. Disbelieving. Overcome.
We didn’t want to wake you.  93.
You were watching me sleep. He smiles to himself.

Tilt down from the sky to a festive SMALL TOWN PARADE. Families, teenagers, the elderly, all line the curb. Marching down the street: attractive women in red, white blue leotards. Members of the local Chamber of Commerce i behind the twirlers in a vintage Cadillac. Banners read “HAPPY MEMORIAL DAY.”

A group of college-age kids, set back from the crowd, sit around an SUV, drinking, grilling. An adorable, long-legged girl in sparkle-y FACE PAINT (21 makes eyes at... A dangerous looking guy in a VISOR (26), standing way in corner, with his back to the WOODS. He takes a sip of bee She looks away. Then looks back.
They make out against a tree. The parade isn’t too far aw we can still hear faint music, applause.
(takes her hand) Come on.
Where are we going? He leads her deeper into the woods. They pause every few trees to kiss some more.
Shoes, flip-flops come off. Unzipping; they are both stepping on their shorts, prying them off their ankles. Breaking the kiss, he takes her shirt off, chucks it.
Let’s go.

Wait wait wait. Hold on. She dips her toe in, testing. He grabs her, pulls her clo more kissing, kinda sloppy. As they pull apart, a shape emerges drifts on the water behind them trees behind them JOE. Asleep in the tire. Looking like shit, sun-blasted, filthy and too thin. They see him.
Ohmigod! Joe wakes up.
(groggy) Wha...? Pat--oh, Jesus-- Joe averts his eyes. The girl grabs her shirt, looking to cover up quickly.
Kid! What the fuck man! He and her dart off into the woods.
(to himself) Sorry... They’re gone. Joe looks at the empty spot where they disappeared into the woods.
Joe wanders, tossing twigs around, aimless. Stumbling abo like a man who’s been in the desert for days.

location: HOUSE IN THE WOODS, FIRE PIT

text: Joe jams flint against a twig, into a pile of dry sticks leaves. He’s awkward, sometimes missing the twig entirely It’s not working.  95.
He opens the cooler. Scraps of odd, unidentifiable meat. Four berries in the bottom of a basket. A rotten apple.
Overcome by hunger, he closes his eyes and eats a bunch o PURPLE BERRIES.
Wide. Joe VOMITS some purple stuff into the stream.
Joe looks in the petty cash box. Just some change. Not ev quarters.
Shit.
